oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery interviews Ronnie Milsap
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording is from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of Ronnie Milsap (performer) for the Ralph Emery Show. The tape is recorded at Milsap Studio. The recording is from April 29, 1992.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Ronnie Milsap
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Ralph Emery and Ronnie Milsap joke off-air -- (00:13) Emery introduces Milsap to the Ralph Emery Show, and Emery asks Milsap what "All is Fair in Love and War" is about -- (02:46) Emery inquires about Milsap's writing aspirations -- (04:32) Emery inquires as to if distractions affect Milsap's ability to write -- (04:54) Emery ask Milsap to reflect on his studio: Ground Star Laboratory -- (06:17) Emery and Milsap discuss 'perfect pitch' -- (07:51) Emery asks Milsap to reflect on the notes consistent on a dial tone -- (09:25) Emery and Milsap praise the success of Mike Reid, and Emery inquires about some of the songs Reid had written -- (15:13) Emery and Milsap discuss "Pure Love," and Milsap's reaction to his first number-one record -- (18:58) Emery inquires about Milsap's most successful record; that record was "There's No Getting Over Me" -- (19:33) Emery recalls how Milsap sung about his traveling nature, and Milsap talks about how he would travel all over the coast -- (23:10) Emery asks Milsap if he ever had a reckless driving ticket -- (27:22) Emery and Milsap discuss the day where Milsap got into fights three times in one day -- (32:45) Emery asks Milsap to describe the game of 'Scratch' -- (33:50) Emery praises Milsap, and both discuss Milsap's acoustic abilities -- (36:01) Emery inquires about the placement of objects in Milsap's home, and Milsap reflects on the desire to move to Nashville -- (40:15) Emery tells a joke by Faron Young, and Milsap and Emery reflect on Young and George Jones' alcoholism -- (42:22) Emery asks Milsap to play a word association game for: "What Goes on When the Sun Goes Down," "It Was Almost Like a Song," "Back on My Mind Again," "Only One Love in My Life," "Smoky Mountain Rain," "Am I Losing You?," and "Day Dreams about Night Things" -- (53:09) Emery and Milsap discuss "A Woman in Love" and David Briggs -- (54:56) Milsap reflects on the Louvin Brothers' influence when thinking about "Turn That Radio On" -- (56:41) Milsap associates Emmylou Harris to "Please Don't Tell Me How the Story Ends" -- (57:41) Milsap associates "(I'm a) Stand By My Woman, Man" to a time in a club -- (1:00:24) Milsap reflects on how a song that he recorded was turned down by the Oak Ridge Boys -- (1:03:15) Emery and Milsap say their goodbyes, and both joke about Kris Kristofferson off-air
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Milsap, Ronnie; Emery, Ralph;
